Hi, I worked at McDonald‚Äôs in France for a while, and one of the first things you learn is that differentiating Ice Tea, Coca Cola and Coca Cola Zero is really hard when there‚Äôs a lid and it‚Äôs easy to get mixed up (I noticed after a while that Ice Tea bubbles are yellow).

I am very open about my autism and I also do this, and I don‚Äôt know if people remember that I‚Äôm autistic. Also, I don‚Äôt use as an excuse so I apologise later. Recently, I apologised to my ex roommate from boarding school, as I had been for three years in the same room and I had been annoying and impossible to live with, as I was not even self diagnosed yet. She was also annoying, so we didn‚Äôt get along too well. On top of that, internalised homophobia (I‚Äôm a lesbian and she‚Äôs bi) from me, being jealous of her openness about her sexuality, etc.
I ignored her for a year (we‚Äôre in the same uni, same classes) and then I apologised a month ago, during our second year. I was awful and a complete arsehole and she forgived me.

I don‚Äôt know if those people will forgive you, but you can try to apologise if you feel like it.

Yes, of course it‚Äôs a coping method. I would describe it as creating your own stimuli in order to
- overwhelm you in a good way (a child is happy so he stims) OR 
- drown out the other stimuli / occupy part of your mind to help you concentrate
- regulate emotions (can‚Äôt really explain)

To be exact, autistic people do it on their own. If your child doesn‚Äôt stim in a way or another, think about whether you‚Äôve (or a another person) stopped/forbid them for stimming.
